stars.name: Sun
stars.resume: Our Sun is a 4.5 billion-year-old star – a hot, glowing ball of hydrogen and helium at the centre of our solar system. Without its energy, life as we know it could not exist here on our home planet. The Sun is the largest object in our solar system. About 1.3 million Earths would be needed to fill the Sun’s volume. Its gravity holds the solar system together, keeping everything from the largest planets to the smallest pieces of debris in orbit around it. The hottest part of the Sun is its core, where temperatures reach 15 million degrees Celsius. The Sun’s activity, from its powerful eruptions to the constant flow of charged particles it sends, influences the nature of space throughout the solar system.
curiosities: The Sun accounts for 99.8% of the total mass of the Solar System.
Every second, the Sun converts about 600 million tons of hydrogen into helium.

planets.name: Mercury
planets.resume: The smallest planet in our solar system and closest to the Sun, Mercury is only slightly larger than Earth’s Moon. From Mercury’s surface, the Sun would appear more than three times larger than when seen from Earth, and sunlight would be seven times brighter. Despite its proximity to the Sun, Mercury is not the hottest planet in our solar system – that title belongs to neighbouring Venus, thanks to its dense atmosphere. Because of Mercury’s egg-shaped elliptical orbit and slow rotation, the Sun appears to rise briefly, set, and rise again from some parts of the planet’s surface. The same happens in reverse at sunset.
curiosities: A day on Mercury lasts 176 Earth days.
Despite being closest to the Sun, it is not the hottest planet in the Solar System.

planets.name: Venus
planets.resume: Venus is the second planet from the Sun and Earth’s closest planetary neighbour. Venus has a thick, toxic atmosphere filled with carbon dioxide and is perpetually shrouded in thick, yellowish clouds of sulphuric acid that trap heat, causing a runaway greenhouse effect. It is the hottest planet in our solar system, even though Mercury is closer to the Sun. Venus rotates on its axis backwards compared to most other planets in the solar system. This means that on Venus, the Sun rises in the west and sets in the east.
curiosities: A day on Venus is longer than a Venusian year.
Venus rotates in a retrograde direction, meaning the Sun rises in the west and sets in the east.

planets.name: Earth
planets.resume: Our home planet is the third planet from the Sun, and the only place we know so far that is inhabited by living beings. Although Earth is only the fifth largest planet in the solar system, it is the only world in our solar system with liquid water on its surface. Just slightly larger than neighbouring Venus, Earth is the largest of the four planets closest to the Sun, all made of rock and metal. The name Earth is at least 1,000 years old. All the planets, except Earth, were named after Greek and Roman gods and goddesses. However, the name Earth is a Germanic word, which simply means “the soil”.
curiosities: Earth is the only known planet to support life.
About 70% of Earth's surface is covered by water.

planets.name: Mars
planets.resume: Mars is the fourth planet from the Sun, the second smallest in the Solar System. Named after the Roman god of war, it is often described as the 'Red Planet' because the iron oxide prevalent on its surface gives it a reddish appearance – a dusty, cold, desert world with a very thin atmosphere. Mars is also a dynamic planet with seasons, polar ice caps, canyons, extinct volcanoes and evidence that it was even more active in the past.
curiosities: Mars has the largest volcano in the Solar System, Olympus Mons.
It has two small moons: Phobos and Deimos.

planets.name: Jupiter
planets.resume: Jupiter has a long history of surprising scientists – ever since 1610, when Galileo Galilei discovered the first moons beyond Earth. This discovery changed the way we see the universe. Fifth in line from the Sun, Jupiter is by far the largest planet in the solar system – more than twice the mass of all the other planets combined. The familiar stripes and swirls of Jupiter are actually cold, windy clouds of ammonia and water, floating in an atmosphere of hydrogen and helium. Jupiter’s iconic Great Red Spot is a giant storm, larger than Earth, that has raged for hundreds of years.
curiosities: The Great Red Spot is a storm that has lasted for at least 350 years.
It is the most massive planet in the Solar System, with more than 75 confirmed moons.

planets.name: Saturn
planets.resume: Saturn is the sixth planet from the Sun and the second largest planet in our solar system. Adorned with beautiful rings, Saturn is unique among the planets. It is not the only planet to have rings – made of chunks of ice and rock – but none are as spectacular or as complex as Saturn’s. Like gas giant Jupiter, Saturn is a massive ball made mostly of hydrogen and helium.
curiosities: Saturn has the largest ring system in the Solar System.
Its density is so low that it would float in a giant ocean of water.

planets.name: Uranus
planets.resume: Uranus is the seventh planet from the Sun and has the third largest diameter in our solar system. It was the first planet discovered with the help of a telescope, in 1781 by astronomer William Herschel, although he originally thought it was a comet or a star. Two years later, the object was universally accepted as a new planet, partly due to observations by astronomer Johann Elert Bode.
curiosities: Uranus rotates almost on its side, with an axial tilt of 98°.
Its seasons last about 21 years each.

planets.name: Neptune
planets.resume: Dark, cold, and whipped by supersonic winds, the ice giant Neptune is the eighth and farthest planet in our solar system. More than 30 times farther from the Sun than Earth, Neptune is the only planet in our solar system not visible to the naked eye and the first predicted by mathematics before its discovery. In 2011, Neptune completed its first 165-year orbit since its discovery in 1846. NASA’s Voyager 2 is the only spacecraft to have visited Neptune up close, flying by in 1989 as it exited the solar system.

discovery.by: Urbain Le Verrier and Johann Galle

curiosities: Neptune has the fastest winds in the Solar System, reaching up to 2,100 km/h.
It was the first planet discovered by mathematical calculations before being observed.

dwarfPlanets.name: Pluto
dwarfPlanets.resume: In 2006, Pluto was reclassified as a dwarf planet. Essentially, the main reason that led the International Astronomical Union (IAU) to remove Pluto from the list of planets is the fact that it is not able to clear its own orbit, meaning it depends on other celestial bodies to influence its path – in this case, Neptune on one side, and various frozen objects from the Kuiper Belt on the other. Pluto – which is smaller than Earth’s Moon – has a heart-shaped glacier the size of Texas and Oklahoma. This fascinating world has blue skies, spinning moons, mountains as tall as the Rockies, and it snows – but the snow is red.
curiosities: Pluto has a moon, Charon, almost the same size as itself.
Its orbit is so tilted that sometimes it is closer to the Sun than Neptune.

dwarfPlanets.name: Haumea
dwarfPlanets.resume: Haumea is a rapidly rotating dwarf planet located in the Kuiper Belt. It is known for its elongated, egg-like shape and fast rotation period, making it unique among other dwarf planets.

discovery.by: Mike Brown, Chad Trujillo, David Rabinowitz

curiosities: Haumea has a ring system, making it the first trans-Neptunian object discovered with rings.
It rotates so quickly that it is shaped like an ellipsoid rather than a sphere.
dwarfPlanets.geography: Haumea's surface is covered with crystalline water ice and it has two known moons: Hiʻiaka and Namaka.

dwarfPlanets.name: Makemake
dwarfPlanets.resume: Makemake is one of the largest known objects in the Kuiper Belt and is notable for being the second-brightest dwarf planet after Pluto. It is covered with methane, ethane, and possibly nitrogen ices.

discovery.by: Mike Brown, Chad Trujillo, David Rabinowitz

curiosities: Makemake was discovered shortly after Easter and is named after the creator god of the Rapa Nui people of Easter Island.
It has one known moon, discovered in 2016.
dwarfPlanets.geography: Makemake's surface is very bright and covered with frozen methane and possibly nitrogen.

dwarfPlanets.name: Eris
dwarfPlanets.resume: Eris is the most massive known dwarf planet in the Solar System and is located in the scattered disk beyond the Kuiper Belt. Its discovery was a key factor in the reclassification of Pluto as a dwarf planet.

discovery.by: Mike Brown, Chad Trujillo, David Rabinowitz

curiosities: Eris has one known moon, Dysnomia.
It is sometimes farther from the Sun than any other known dwarf planet.
dwarfPlanets.geography: Eris is a distant, icy world with a highly elliptical orbit and a surface covered with methane ice.

asteroids.name: Ceres
asteroids.resume: Ceres is the largest object in the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter and is classified as both an asteroid and a dwarf planet. It contains about a third of the mass of the entire asteroid belt.
curiosities: Ceres was the first asteroid to be discovered.
It has been visited by NASA's Dawn spacecraft.
asteroids.geography: Ceres has a rocky core and an icy mantle, and may have a subsurface ocean of liquid water.

asteroids.name: Vesta
asteroids.resume: Vesta is one of the largest asteroids in the asteroid belt and is known for its bright surface and differentiated structure.
curiosities: Vesta has a differentiated structure with core, mantle, and crust.
It is the brightest asteroid visible from Earth.
asteroids.geography: Vesta's surface features include large impact basins and a variety of terrains.

asteroids.name: Eros
asteroids.resume: Eros is a near-Earth asteroid and one of the first to be studied by a spacecraft. It has an elongated, irregular shape.
curiosities: Eros was the first asteroid orbited by a spacecraft (NEAR Shoemaker).
It is a potential resource for future space mining.
asteroids.geography: Eros has a heavily cratered surface and an elongated, peanut-like shape.

galaxies.name: Milky Way
galaxies.resume: The Milky Way is the galaxy that contains our Solar System, appearing as a hazy band of light in the night sky from Earth.
curiosities: Our galaxy is a barred spiral galaxy.
It contains an estimated 100–400 billion stars.
galaxies.geography: The Milky Way has several spiral arms and a central bulge containing a supermassive black hole.

galaxies.name: Andromeda
galaxies.resume: The Andromeda Galaxy is the nearest spiral galaxy to the Milky Way and is expected to collide with it in about 4.5 billion years.
curiosities: Andromeda is on a collision course with the Milky Way.
It is visible to the naked eye from Earth.
galaxies.geography: Andromeda contains hundreds of billions of stars and many satellite galaxies.
